How is this news?
Haven't we known this since the stone age?

Wolves form packs. There's the ability to differentiate different languages and individuals ten times over.

Today we also know for a fact that whales (dolphins, orcas, blue, humpback, spermwhales etc.), many species of birds, wolves (and by default dogs), elephants, monkeys etc can differentiate not just sound but also sound patterns in packs and individuals. And on top of that they can often recognize individual humans, and if those humans different speech patterns than usual etc.

So of course they can recognize if you sound like an angry bumblebee (Hispanic), like a stuck elevator playing the same romantic song over and over again (french) like the devil incarnate (people from texas), or like an angel from heaven (hoarse cat).

You often blow my mind, so let me see if I can manage to wow you guys with something.

I know you know what CRISPR CAS-9 is.
I know you know it is theorized to be able to have the potential to allow us to utilize sections of a strand of RNA from DNA for gene therapy.

Okay.
Our Bodies use Calcium Carbonate (CaCO3) to create our bones, nothing amazing yet...bear with me...You will have a BOMBSHELL of an idea drop in your lap.

Our bones are relatively brittle, however, right?

I present the conjecture that if we could somehow utilize Aluminum, to have our bodies Synthesize Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3), then we would have much stronger bones.
Sapphire Bones.

But how would Science be able to create a strand of RNA that allows an organism to take in and utilize Aluminum to synthesize Al2O3 in that manner?

A pipe dream? Fantasy? Day Dreams?

No, not necessarily.

Let us journey to the bottom of the Ocean to seek the Giant Roly-Polys of the Sea, Deep Sea Amphipods.

At those pressures Calcium Carbonate (CaCO3) dissolves away, bad if you are trying to stay alive.

To circumvent this, they do something amazing.

Amphipods take in Aluminum from it's surroundings and uses it to reinforce it's Exoskeleton with Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3).

Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3) is known colloquially as Sapphire, Ruby, Codundum, but it goes by other names as well.

Can you tell what I am leading up to?


Sapphire, or Corundum, is 9 on the Mohs Hardness Scale, almost as hard as Diamond itself, of course.
It also happens to go by the name of Adamantite.

IF they figure out how to isolate the sequence that allows for Al2O3 Synthesis from Deep Sea Amphipods the figure out a way to have it target and replace the sequence in Humans for our bones...which isn't implausible...
Well...
It means, probably IN our lifetime, we will see Humans with Adamantium Skeletons.

Yes.
Adamantium Skeletons

Told you I would BLOW your mind...

I think dogs do not have the concept for a language. What they are good at is learning that when they hear specific words they need to do certain tasks. Either for a treat or to please their owner. Dogs do not understand the meaning of our words. What they do understand is the tone and the energy we put into our words. They can differentiate the specific words (commands) from all the other. They get used to the general rhythm of the language. Based on this dog's cannot be bilingual, since they neither understand the meaning of our words nor can speak any of our languages. They can sense if the general tone and rhythm of the surrounding language has changed. I am Bulgarian and my golden retriever can easily follow the commands in Bulgarian. When I say the same command with the same tone and energy and voice  in English my dog is confused. He can guess that this is something familiar, but the noise (word/command) is different. And is not quite sure what is expected of him. To me this means that dogs need tone, general rhythm and actual words to understand us.

This intriguing experiment provides evidence for familiarity/unfamiliarity with certain sounds rather than with "language" as such. As Magyar and Spanish are in different Language Families (Uralic and Indo-European), the differences are more marked. I suspect that, if the languages were more closely related (say Spanish and Italian), the evidence for different brain processing would be less obvious. Humans, for example, with sufficient training, can distinguish the subtle differences between the songs of different birds within the same species. I am unaware of any experiment that tried a null-set case where the notes of the song were randomly scrambled, but I suspect that we could pick that up as "wrong" somehow. I do not think that says much about linguistic processing, though. In this experiment, we are probably seeing something closer to how novel and the habitual sounds are processed differently in the brain, with the former generating a dopamine hit to "pay attention!" and the latter has habitually moved into the background of the soundscape until a command or treat opportunity presents itself.

this was one of the first things i noticed when i moved to germany with my dog: he would not respond to people talking to him on the streets and in trains. however, after our german neighbour started taking him out for some rides, he got much better at it, and eventually could acknowledge when he was being spoken to by others in german. i think this ability has gone down again since our neighbour moved.
I actually studied at this university, and did see doggies being brought in. Though that was quite the usual thing with the biology faculty. one time they even walked in with a pig.

Since all animals kinda have their own language and don't naturally understand any other language than their own unless it's specifically taught to them, it seems logical to me that this also applies to dogs.

I don't know why it is so surprising, or should be limited to dogs. We don't call language the way animals communicate, but it's basically a language. So, all animals are exposed to different languages all the time, as they share their environment with other species, therefore their languages (and even more when they are “pets”, living with us). For example, we know that animals of different species take advantage of each other alarm calls to avoid danger in nature. Which means for my little brain that not only they actually "understand" each others, or at least they are able to differentiate informations given by others, even if it's not in their own “language”, but also, and probably more remarkably, they collaborate! I think we as humans should step down our illusory superior pedestal, and start to see things as they are. I am sure we will be amazed by what we'll discover, like the things that are under our nose since centuries, but we couldn't see because of our arrogance...

I tend to think humans underestimate non human animals a lot. Take my Goats and me and then imagine that they have arms and hands like mine but still behaved as Goats. How long do you think it would take for their behavior to change? My point is they are confined to the body of a Goat so even if they could perceive everything as I can they would still be confined to the survival behaviors of a Goat. However in saying that they also display all the behaviors that humans display too, most animals do if they can. A big problem now I think is a lot of people never get to know enough types of animal to get a handle on just how smart they are and when they do encounter animals the animal is usually confined to a not so natural environment like a zoo or farm. But if you can spend time with a good number of different species in a more natural setting you may find that they are not so different to you. It's amusing, once we get to know an animal personally we ascribe "person-hood" to it by being able to define it's having a specific "personality" that you can tell out of a group of others of it's same species. If we are ascribing person-hood in this way to non humans, to me it would follow that they also have intelligence in a similar way.

I have known this for a long time. My dad used to train dogs in both Italian and English. Our current dog understands a fair amount of both. They can also tell the difference between when someone is speaking a language they understand with a different accent, because they generally pause to comprehend then do the command.

I'm not that surprised. Dogs learn commands by their owners' body language, vocal tone, and gestures as much as, or more so, than the words themselves. But they certainly will know when a human voice sounds weird to them compared to the usual noises we make in their presence. That may not mean language recognition, but it certainly shows recognition of sound differences. And dogs are certainly way more sensitive to sound than we are.
I'm more and more convinced that we're in the process of uplifting dogs. I wonder what they will be capable of in 10,000 years.

If you think about it, many working dogs understand not only the language spoken by the owner, but also hand signals, whistles and various other methods of communication.  In some respects, that's a larger skillset than most humans, especially if you add in their ability to speak dog.

The Lurcher Trixie (Bordercollie/ Greyhound <del>17 years old when she died) was a very clever dog. She soon learned all Swedish words for all things important to her. Peoples' names, places, things to do, food items, events in the weekend... everything. Then the family started to say the words one letter at a time instead. She got it. Then the same in English - and Greek</del> and Spanish! No more languages was spoken in the household so her humans just gave up.... This is the dog who always found the latest toy you got for her and welcomed you at the door with it, before you even rang the doorbell. No matter if you got her something a year or two ago. She knew. Looking you in the eyes, she offered the toy she carried in her mouth, pushed you gently with her nose, took the toy and ran back with it in to the house. Just to get the toy the next person had gotten her. Even if many guests came at the same time, and guests bringing their kids and their own dogs (total chaos) or if the toy haden't been used for months and lay hidden somewhere. She was more than a dog. Miss her and my own dog (lurcher Bordercollie/Whippet) every day.

But I think this is also true for dogs as well as cats.
My real native language is Chinese(Shanghainese), my official native language is Chinese(Mandarin), and I learned English when I was a kid.
As a result, normally when I give instructions to my dog and cat it is typically in English (sit, stay, shake-hand, etc.); but daily conversations are half-English and half-Mandarin. However, when I get EXTREMELY strong emotions such as seeing my cat knocking over my very expensive bottle of perfume or my dog trying to play-bite my laptop, I shout/yell at them in Shanghainese.
I noticed that sometimes during normal daily conversation, the moment I start speaking Shanghainese, whenever that happens, they almost immediately freezes and look at me with those cute and innocent eyes as if they were saying "No I didn't do that". Even if I don't raise or change my tone.
I wonder if this is because they figured out the difference between English, Mandarin and Shanghainese?
